section-block.rac_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra
section-block.rac_book_summary: A boy works with his family, friends, and neighbors to make his neighborhood more beautiful.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about the neighborhood where they live. Ask how they could make their neighborhoods more beautiful.
Have children act out the things they will read about: dancing, building a snowman, eating an ice cream cone, and painting.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Hey, Wall written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra.
Scout loves stories. Stories are also called narratives. This is a narrative about a boy who wants to make his neighborhood more beautiful.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do we learn about where the boy lives?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you see in this picture? What is the boy holding? What things are on the ground? Let’s find out what this boy is going to do.
The boy says, “You are BIG. A city block BIG.” Who is he talking to? Who remembers what a city block is?
How do you think the boy is going to change the wall?
Who are the people in this picture? What are they holding? What do you think they are going to do?
The boy says they will fill the wall with energy.
What types of pictures did the people paint on the wall? Do you think the wall is beautiful now? Why? Why not?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What do we learn about where the boy lives?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We learn that he lives in a city.
We learn that it snows in the winter.
We learn that an ice cream truck comes by in the summer.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about the city block as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the boy live in a city or on a farm?
The boy lives in a c_____ (city).
The boy lives in a city.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: What children learn in one language will transfer to other languages naturally. For example, once children learn about community in their home language, they don’t need to relearn the same concepts in English. They simply need to learn the corresponding vocabulary in English.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Flexible Thinking and Behavior
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about a time when children think one thing, but then changed their minds to think about something different. What made them change their minds? Explain that when we show flexible thinking and behavior, we change what we normally think in response to a new situation, event, or information.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Hey, Wall written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra. We will talk about being flexible in our thinking and behavior.
Scout knows this story is a narrative, or story, with people who could be real. They act just like real people. We call this a realistic narrative. Who can say that?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Grandma Addy says there was “a time when our neighborhood was beautiful.” What does the boy think about the wall? Do you think what his grandma said will change his mind? (MB)
What does the boy have at home to help him make the wall more beautiful?
The boy’s friends and family helped come up with ideas for the wall. How did Grandma Addy help? How did James and Danny help?

At the beginning of the book, the boy thought the wall was “cold, old, and empty.” (page 4), but now he says that the wall has “become our blank canvas.” How do the boy and his neighbors use the wall to make the neighborhood beautiful again? (MB)
What does the wall look like now? How is it different from what it looked like at the beginning of the story? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to use their flexible thinking as they sort a group of objects by color, then resort them by shape. Explain that resorting the same objects in a different way shows that they are using flexible thinking. Ask children if they can think of another way to sort the objects (e.g., by size, weight, texture, etc.).
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how the boy and his neighbors made the wall beautiful.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The flexible thinking skill enables us to apply different rules in different situations. We use flexible thinking when we try a new food, go to a new place, categorize things in a new way, and more. We aren’t born with this skill, but we all have the ability to practice and improve at any stage of life! (Parenttoolkit.com/Pre-K/Self-awareness)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children to make smart guesses about what happens next.
Hold up the covers of different books that your children may not have read and ask them to predict what the book will be about.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are reading Hey, Wall written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra.
Scout loves Hey, Wall because he likes stories about people who seem like real people.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What does the boy think about the wall at the beginning of the story?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can tell me what you see in this picture? What does the wall look like?
page 7
Why do Danny and her friends build their snowmen on other sidewalks, not in front of the wall?
Why do the people keep their eyes down? Why do they not look up at the wall? Where are they looking?
Who can make a prediction, or a smart guess, about what is going to happen next?
Who can show me the sketches? Who brought their sketches? How will the sketches help make the wall more beautiful?
Who is staring at the wall? Pretend that you are staring at the wall.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
What does the boy think about the wall at the beginning of the story?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He thinks the wall is ugly.
He thinks the wall is cold.
He thinks the wall is empty.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about the boy and the wall, inviting children to add end punctuation.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the boy think the wall is ugly or beautiful?
He thinks the wall is u______ (ugly).
He thinks the wall is ugly.
Why does he want to change the wall?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Ask children questions to help them go further in their learning. By carefully challenging children to go little by little, they will feel a sense of growth and accomplishment without being overwhelmed. Differentiate your questions as needed to help all children continue to grow and learn.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to think about where we live. We’re going to think about the different stores and buildings in our town.

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that bakeries are stores that sell bread, cakes, and muffins. Ask if children have a bakery in their town. Then lead them in singing “The Muffin Man.”

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Our Neighborhood. It is a poster that gives us information. We call it an informational poster.
Scout loves to look at posters because he likes to learn new information.
Hey, Wall and Our Neighborhood show us places where we live. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the Hey, Wall book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What is it like where we live?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Where We Live
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then use these prompts for discussion.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This is a map of a neighborhood. How can you tell that this is a map?
Can you find the library? How do you know that it is the library? Have you visited the library in your town?
To send a letter to a friend, you would need to go to the post office. Can you point to the post office? Trace a line with your finger from the library to the post office.
How are the city in the book and the city on the poster the same? What do they both have? How are they different?

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw a picture of themselves in front of a building in their neighborhood to show that they are aware of their own body within their surroundings. Encourage children to draw other buildings in their community to add to their neighborhood map.(MB)
Provide a writing prompt about where we live and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Learning Same and Different
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children can understand how objects are the same or different. Begin with concrete things. For example, point out if several children are wearing the same color shirt. Then point out different shirt colors. Eventually you will be able to compare more abstract concepts such as interests.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children act out different people and events in Hey, Wall and Our Neighborhood. Have children pretend to draw a sketch for the wall. Have them pretend to be a firefighter putting out a big fire; a barber cutting someone’s hair; and a server in the restaurant filling a customer’s glass with water.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell Hey, Wall written by Susan Verde and illustrated by John Parra. How do we retell a story?
Scout knows this book is a realistic narrative. It’s not a true story, but the people look and act real.
This week we read about a boy who wanted to make his neighborhood more beautiful. As I read the book again, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What is life like in a big city?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Tell me everything you see in this picture. Is it a big city or a little town? How can you tell?
What do you see in this picture? Do you think the wall is beautiful? Why or why not?
Why are the children cheering for tiny flowers pushing through the cracks in the sidewalk? Why are the plants reaching for sunlight? Let’s cheer for the tiny flowers.
What are the people on these pages doing? Let’s act out what we see. Who is spinning? Pretend you are spinning with a partner. You may get dizzy!
People are painting “up on ladders and way down low.” Pretend that you are painting up high on ladders. Now pretend that you are painting way down low.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is life like in a big city?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: People like to dance and listen to music.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about what they would show if they painted a big wall near where they live.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Are there many people or few people in a city?
There are m______ (many) people in a city.
There are many people in a city.
Do you live in a big city? How is your neighborhood like this city?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children’s curiosity about the natural world by creating an environment that celebrates curiosity, observation, and inquiry. Encourage children to observe, ask questions, draw, and discuss what they see. Focus on what children can observe directly and on plants and animals in the environment in which they live.
